description: Simple declarative sentence without punctuation should receive a period at the end
spokenText: the report is ready and has been sent to the client
expectedOutput: The report is ready and has been sent to the client.

description: Direct question without punctuation should receive a question mark at the end
spokenText: what time does the meeting start
expectedOutput: What time does the meeting start?

description: Exclamatory sentence expressing strong emotion should receive an exclamation mark
spokenText: i cant believe we actually won the contract
expectedOutput: I can't believe we actually won the contract!

description: Ambiguous intonation — 'you're coming tomorrow' could be a question or a statement depending on context, so both are acceptable
Rhetorical question — technically a question form but may also be treated as an exclamation, both are valid
spokenText: who would have thought we would get this far
expectedOutput: Who would have thought we would get this far?

description: Multi-sentence passage with mixed punctuation — a statement, a question, and an exclamation should each receive appropriate end marks
spokenText: the deployment finished at noon did anyone check the logs the error rate dropped to zero thats incredible
expectedOutput: The deployment finished at noon. Did anyone check the logs? The error rate dropped to zero, that's incredible!
